<p>COVID-19 is having a significant impact on morbidity and mortality across the world, with a current worldwide death total, as of June 2, of more than 376,000 people.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="948a691d-535a-4223-b7cd-22ad55b0e9b6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="948a691d-535a-4223-b7cd-22ad55b0e9b6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">COVID-19 case tracker, John Hopkins University, accessed on June 2, 2020, coronavirus.jhu.edu.</span></span></span></a></span> The initial focus of all countries response has been to address the critical needs of COVID-19 patients. However, hidden acute and chronic implications of the outbreak could have deeper impact across the population.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" <p>Some evidence already exists of a major, indirect, and undermanaged health impact. Data from many countries across Europe are showing significant increases in excess deaths<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="430aebe5-90e2-4402-897d-fec119078e22"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="430aebe5-90e2-4402-897d-fec119078e22" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Excess deaths, also called excess mortality, is the gap between the total number of people who died from any cause, and the historical average for the same place and time of year. These metrics are collected and reported by national bodies in most European countries (see also Exhibit 1).</span></span></span></a></span> in March and April 2020. While many are likely attributable directly to COVID-19, up to 50 percent in some regions are recorded as non-COVID-19-related<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d5c97b76-bf01-4de5-b932-3bc11804acd4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d5c97b76-bf01-4de5-b932-3bc11804acd4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Comparatively, during a recent heavy flu season, roughly 25 percent of excess deaths were attributable to influenza. See Nielsen J et al., European all-cause excess and influenza-attributable mortality in the 2017/18 season: should the burden of influenza B be reconsidered? <em>Clinical Microbiology and Infection</em>, 2019, Volume 25, Number 10, pp. 126676.</span></span></span></a></span> (Exhibit 1). It is possible that these effects are driven in part by health services cancellation and care avoidance, but data to truly understand the causes are limited.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/understanding%20and%20managing%20the%20hidden%20health%20crisis%20of%20covid%2019/svg-hidden-health-crisis-exhibit-1-v3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Excess deaths per 100000 population, March-April 2020." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/understanding%20and%20managing%20the%20hidden%20health%20crisis%20of%20covid%2019/svg-hidden-health-crisis-exhibit-1-v3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>COVID-19 may produce further, longer-term consequences, not just from reduced care provision, but from the impact of lockdowns on mental and physical health. As the economic downturn continues, and unemployment rises, even greater deleterious tangential effects stemming from the pandemic may arise.</p>
<p>While uncertainty remains, understanding the possible causes of this hidden health impact, and starting to monitor them closely, are among critical first steps for governments and health systems.</p>
<p>This article sets out some of these hidden effects, and outlines six considerations for governments and health system leaders as they design their response.</p>
<h2>The health impact of COVID-19 can be grouped into four categories:</h2>
<h3>1. Direct health effects of COVID-19</h3>
<p>As of early May, rates of new hospitalizations and deaths from COVID-19 were slowing in parts of Europe.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c4dcbaa0-9a26-476e-be25-d3a039b17e57"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c4dcbaa0-9a26-476e-be25-d3a039b17e57" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">COVID-19 situation update worldwide, European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, May 6, 2020, ecdc.europa.eu.</span></span></span></a></span> However, health systems will need to continue to support those who survive the disease. Many patients requiring intensive care for COVID-19 are developing multi-organ failure.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4f5c3667-8f0e-4b55-940f-0854892edf47"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4f5c3667-8f0e-4b55-940f-0854892edf47" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">ICNARC report on COVID-19 in critical care, Intensive Care National Audit and Research Centre, May 1, 2020, icnarc.org.</span></span></span></a></span> There also are early reports of possible long-term damage to lungs and other organs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5b666022-c31f-42ee-9d17-640ad46710a5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5b666022-c31f-42ee-9d17-640ad46710a5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Pan Y et al. Initial CT findings and temporal changes in patients with the novel coronavirus pneumonia (2019-nCoV): a study of 63 patients in Wuhan, China, <em>European Radiology</em>, February 13, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a587a769-427e-4e41-9282-365f33ec42a5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a587a769-427e-4e41-9282-365f33ec42a5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Tian S et al., Pathological study of the 2019 novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19) through postmortem core biopsies, <em>Modern Pathology</em>, April 14, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/healthcare/how-we-help-clients">Healthcare Systems & Services Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/healthcare/how-we-help-clients/americas/healthcare-innovation" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Visit our Healthcare Innovation page</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<h3>2. Implications of reduced non-COVID-19 health services and care avoidance</h3>
<p>Many health systems across Europe have cancelled or postponed tens of thousands of elective procedures and outpatient appointments.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4ef878e6-d03a-4e50-afe1-fa9783e69196"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4ef878e6-d03a-4e50-afe1-fa9783e69196" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Beyond containment: Health systems responses to COVID-19 in the OECD, Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, updated April 16, 2020, oecd.org.</span></span></span></a></span> Care service levels are likely to remain affected for many months, and reinstating capacity cannot be instantaneous. For example, consider the need to ensure a robust personal protective equipment (PPE) supply chain, retain capacity for COVID-19 patients, and maintain a resilient workforce. The implications of deferring acute care, and support for those with longer-term conditions, may be significant. In England, for cancer alone, the postponement of diagnosis and treatment because of COVID-19 is projected by some to cause 18,000 additional deaths over the next 12 months.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1dce64a6-186d-47fb-b77b-547827033548"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1dce64a6-186d-47fb-b77b-547827033548" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Lai A et al., Estimating excess mortality in people with cancer and multimorbidity in the COVID-19 emergency, ResearchGate, April 2020, researchgate.net.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Many patients have not sought regular medical treatment during the pandemic, which may create short-term impacts. For example, emergency room rates in England for heart attacks fell to nearly half of baseline rates between March 20 and April 20.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="aec8b430-4e20-4d5b-8729-d2e026bd7eec"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="aec8b430-4e20-4d5b-8729-d2e026bd7eec" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Emergency department syndromic surveillance system, Public Health England, April 29, 2020, gov.uk.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3ee55e81-e2bb-4ed8-85c5-13dd61129ad5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3ee55e81-e2bb-4ed8-85c5-13dd61129ad5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">A possible explanation is that physical distancing measures during COVID-19 have led to a decline in triggers for cardiac events, such as exertion from recreational activity, heavy air pollution, anger from being stuck in traffic, and stress from watching a sporting event. However, the underlying cardiovascular disease often associated with heart disease is likely not affected over the short term. See Gump BB and Heffernan K, Why the coronavirus appears tied to fewer heart attacks, <em>U.S. News & World Report</em>, May 11, 2020, usnews.com.</span></span></span></a></span> The implications of treatment avoidance for patients with chronic or longer-term conditions also may be significant. Activity of general practitioners in France reportedly has dropped by 44 percent, and that of outpatient medical specialists by 71 percent between January and April 2020.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="126da745-0ed1-4796-829e-1300616a6960"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="126da745-0ed1-4796-829e-1300616a6960" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Covid-19: Doctolib alerte sur la chute de frquentation des cabinets et sengage pour permettre aux patients de retourner consulter, Doctolib, April 16, 2020, cdn2.hubspot.net.</span></span></span></a></span> According to a survey by the French firm Doctolib,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ebb60c24-cbe1-438f-bef3-84769849cb0c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ebb60c24-cbe1-438f-bef3-84769849cb0c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Doctolib is a French firm that provides a digital platform for booking and conducting primary care and outpatient consultations in Europe (predominantly France and Germany). The survey found that 35 percent of Doctolib patients reported cancelling at least one consultation since the beginning of the pandemic.</span></span></span></a></span> conducted in April, 38 percent of patients cancelling cited the risk of infection, and 28 percent fear of disturbing their doctor during the crisis period.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="eabea4a0-94cc-45ab-af31-988298dfa3b4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="eabea4a0-94cc-45ab-af31-988298dfa3b4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Covid-19: Doctolib alerte sur la chute de frquentation des cabinets et sengage pour permettre aux patients de retourner consulter, Doctolib, April 16, 2020, cdn2.hubspot.net.</span></span></span></a></span> In the United Kingdom, to allow for critical care of COVID-19 patients, many services were stopped, reduced, and/or switched to telephone or video,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="92e64b7f-d8cc-4bf9-9b6b-169d2b0f5a06"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="92e64b7f-d8cc-4bf9-9b6b-169d2b0f5a06" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Joint letter to the Health and Social Care Select Committee for the evidence session on delivering core NHS and care services during the pandemic and beyond, The Health Foundation, The Kings Fund, and Nuffield Trust, May 14, 2020, health.org.uk.</span></span></span></a></span> while general practitioner appointments were down 30 percent in March from the previous year.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="70e48848-912d-473d-b403-72dca89843da"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="70e48848-912d-473d-b403-72dca89843da" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Murray R, Edwards N, and Dixon J, Delivering core NHS and care services during the Covid-19 pandemic and beyond: Letter to the Commons Health and Social Care Select Committee, The King's Fund, May 14, 2020, kingsfund.org.uk.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>While the rapid growth in telemedicine may change access to health advice permanently, it cannot entirely make up the current shortfall. In one example, in Australia, psychiatric admissions were down 39 percent in March 2020 compared to the previous yearwhile lifeline calls are 20 percent higher than for the average summer.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d9af7f63-de02-4ad9-b4ef-8fd188127127"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d9af7f63-de02-4ad9-b4ef-8fd188127127" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Data from the Wesley Hospital, Buderim Private Hospital, and St Andrews Hospital, Australia; and Lifeline.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>3. Direct effects of lockdown</h3>
<p>The lockdown itself is likely to directly impact healthcare needs, both physical and mental. Ninety-three percent of respondents in Italy, during the first week of lockdown, reported being at least a little anxious; 42 percent reported a drop in mood; and 28 percent reported not sleeping well.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="81c3d957-d657-47cd-8588-03124f8d76b6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="81c3d957-d657-47cd-8588-03124f8d76b6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Henley J, Lockdown living: how Europeans are avoiding going stir crazy, <em>Guardian</em>, March 28, 2020, theguardian.com.</span></span></span></a></span> In the United Kingdom, mental health charities are reporting a doubling of reported feelings of loneliness since the lockdown began.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="82737a84-6e6d-4904-9f46-50a5999592b4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="82737a84-6e6d-4904-9f46-50a5999592b4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Almost a quarter of adults living under lockdown in the UK have felt loneliness, Mental Health Foundation, April 22, 2020, mentalhealth.org.uk.</span></span></span></a></span> While the impact of reduced mobility among those with long-term or chronic conditions is unclear, the most immediate reported physical impact is a rise in family violence. Spains governmental helpline for gender-based violence reported a 12 percent increase in call volume in the first two weeks of lockdown, with a 270 percent increase in online consultations of their website.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ea375264-3fab-4c48-b939-fdac0b85a609"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ea375264-3fab-4c48-b939-fdac0b85a609" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Calls to Spains gender violence helpline rise sharply during lockdown, Reuters, April 1, 2020, uk.reuters.com.</span></span></span></a></span> The UNs member states reported up to a 60 percent increase in emergency calls by women subjected to domestic violence in April.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6bd3e7cf-c767-4296-8db9-558374ec3f51"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">21</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6bd3e7cf-c767-4296-8db9-558374ec3f51" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">WHO warns of surge of domestic violence as COVID-19 cases decrease in Europe, United Nations Regional Information Centre for Western Europe, May 7, 2020, unric.org.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>4. Health effects stemming from the long-term economic recession</h3>
<p>In the article <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/safeguarding-europes-livelihoods-mitigating-the-employment-impact-of-covid-19">Safeguarding Europes livelihoods</a>,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="459c8302-adb1-4bb4-9f46-2e3cd17fb123"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">22</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="459c8302-adb1-4bb4-9f46-2e3cd17fb123" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Chinn D, Klier J, Stern S, and Tesfu S, <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/safeguarding-europes-livelihoods-mitigating-the-employment-impact-of-covid-19">Safeguarding Europes livelihoods: Mitigating the employment impact of COVID-19</a>, April 19, 2020, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span> the McKinsey Global Institute estimates that COVID-19 may almost double the unemployment rate in the coming years across Europe. Analysis from previous recessions suggests each 1 percent increase in unemployment correlates to a 0.8 percent rise in suicides<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e4145697-6a51-4cea-b85c-a99874546334"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">23</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e4145697-6a51-4cea-b85c-a99874546334" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Directorate general for internal policies, Mental health in times of economic crisis, European Parliament's Committee on Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, June 19, 2012, europarl.europa.eu.</span></span></span></a></span>: this could mean up to an additional 1,500 to 5,500 suicides in Europe.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8d80a5b7-aa55-4980-974f-4da95e6aebbb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">24</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8d80a5b7-aa55-4980-974f-4da95e6aebbb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Latest EU data show 56,200 persons in the European Union committed suicide in 201516. See Just over 56 000 persons in the EU committed suicide, <em>Eurostat News</em>, July 16, 2018, ec.europa.eu.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="19f8285f-0459-427d-b058-d4d63df4490d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">25</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="19f8285f-0459-427d-b058-d4d63df4490d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Assumes incremental unemployment lasts for 2.5 years on average; see Footnote 5.</span></span></span></a></span> On top of this, there is a strong association between unemployment and life expectancy,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4f39d9d3-6b6e-4f27-9239-36cdb9d3d5f8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">26</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4f39d9d3-6b6e-4f27-9239-36cdb9d3d5f8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Between population cohorts, every additional 10 percentage points of unemployment is associated with a five-year reduction in healthy life expectancy. The direction of causality between these effects likely runs both ways, with many underlying factors contributing in addition.</span></span></span></a></span> which could suggest that the impact on mortality could be substantial. Considering mental health alone, unemployment could lead to the loss of 5.5 million quality-adjusted life years in the EU-27.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6723babb-338b-4ca0-bd2c-023ddf99b7ce"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">27</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6723babb-338b-4ca0-bd2c-023ddf99b7ce" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">A quality-adjusted life year (QALY) is a measure of the state of health of a person or group in which the benefits, in terms of length of life, are adjusted to reflect the quality of life. One QALY is equal to one year of life in perfect health. Our estimated figure is based on the effect of unemployment compared to being employed as 0.1 QALYs (See Norstrm F et al., Does unemployment contribute to poorer health-related quality of life among Swedish adults? <em>BMC Public Health</em>, 2019, Volume 19, Number 457, bmcpublichealth.biomedcentral.com.) The McKinsey Global Institute estimates that the EU-27 unemployment rate could increase by 4.9 percent and peak at 11.2 percent in 2021. The UK Commission for Employment and Skills suggests that following the 2008 financial crisis, it took five years for the unemployment rate to return to pre-2008 recessions levels. On this basis, we assume that unemployment might last on average 2.5 years.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>It will take many months to fully estimate the future impact on all facets of the healthcare system. However, the indirect health implications may potentially outlast and outweigh the direct impact on COVID-19 patients (Exhibit 2).</p>

<p>Governments and health system leaders could review six critical considerations to minimize the longer-term impacts of COVID-19.</p>
<!-- -->
<h2>Consideration No. 1 Create information transparency across the healthcare spectrum</h2>

data-layer-event-prefix="UI Item" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-category="sidebar" data-layer-subcategory="open" data-layer-text="open sidebar"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--radial___y3csX_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-xxl___cL3ZT_990311c mck-plus-no-circle-icon"></span></button></div></div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>The return of elective care</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>Elective surgeries, such as hip and knee replacements or cataract removals, have been paused en masse across Europe.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ee02eeb6-499d-4c58-b9da-9ee62551734f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ee02eeb6-499d-4c58-b9da-9ee62551734f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Tens of millions of surgeries are being postponed as a result of the pandemic, <em>Economist</em>, May 18, 2020, economist.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Three months of cancelled or postponed procedures will generate a significant backlog for healthcare systems, with potential to cause significant detriment to peoples health and well-being.</p>

<h3>Consideration 1</h3>

<p>Healthcare systems could consider tracking how many patients are waiting for elective care and stratifying them by severity of condition. Where possible, health systems could look to monitor some of the known adverse effects of delaying surgery. For example, tracking the mobility of patients waiting for orthopedic procedures, and the vision of those waiting for ophthalmic surgery, so that the burden of disease is known.</p>

<h3>Consideration 2</h3>

<p>Among the questions for system leaders are: How many beds are needed to provide care as normal? What is the workforce requirement to treat these patients? What will be the ongoing demand for critical supplies? All of these issues need to be considered in light of ongoing COVID-19 demands. Systems also may look to change their model of care to better deliver services to patients.</p>

<h3>Consideration 3</h3>

<p>Many of the cancelled procedures will still need to be completed, resulting in a significant backlog of surgeries. It is also reasonable to expect the acuity of some patients needs will have increased due to the delay. Investing in expanding the temporary surge capacity to run down this backlog in a timely fashion will be important. Investing in private sector capacity or extending surgery hours to include weekends are potential solutions.</p>

<h3>Consideration 4</h3>

<p>It is likely that patients have avoided seeking care for conditions that require intervention. The severe drop in emergency department attendances, including for severe acute conditions such as cardiovascular events,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c287a02e-4db9-4cbf-a443-ed63eadedbc6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c287a02e-4db9-4cbf-a443-ed63eadedbc6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Emergency department syndromic surveillance system, Public Health England, April 29, 2020, gov.uk.</span></span></span></a></span> illustrates this point. It will be important for systems to quantify what was underdiagnosed during the COVID-19 crisis response and add these patients to the backlog. Systems then need to implement measures to prevent patients from avoiding care moving forward.</p>

<h3>Consideration 5</h3>

<p>Digital health solutions have seen a proliferation. The implementation of digital telemedicine solutions can support primary and outpatient care, with many systems shifting to virtual care as a default. In England, National Health Service (NHS) data shows that at the end of March 2020, only 54 percent of primary care appointments were taking place face-to-face, compared to 84 percent of appointments at the beginning of the month.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f912fa73-bf68-435f-983c-8a986c53ce8c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f912fa73-bf68-435f-983c-8a986c53ce8c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Appointments in General Practice  March 2020, NHS Digital, April 30, 2020, digital.nhs.uk.</span></span></span></a></span> Understanding the effectiveness of digital appointments as well as the uptake and barriers to adoption across age groups will be important to maintain the digital momentum and adapt elective care long term.</p>

<h3>Consideration 6</h3>

<p>In addition to the backlog, providers may examine whether patients will continue to postpone indefinitely. Cancelling or postponing elective care represents a significant proportion of the care provided by health systems each year. Managing the capacity to work down the backlog and maintain population health during this time will require concerted coordinated efforts across primary and secondary care.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The data and information that health and care systems and governments have available today are often too limited, too fragmented, and too slow. Policy makers and health systems need much broader data feeds that can support fast, data-driven decision making. Specifically, they could:</p>
<ul>
    <li><strong>Move from offline to online reporting.</strong> Each country may consider a system to monitor, in real time, the likely incidence of common events, such as cardiovascular incidents, along with associated morbidity and mortality, in order to permit rapid intervention as needed. This process could be done through strengthening and, where needed, creating real-time observatories actively collating and monitoring data.</li>
    <li><strong>Collect and collate information on all elements relevant to changing population health.</strong> This would include health system metrics (including waiting times, service cancellation, accident and emergency attendance volumes, diagnosis rates and severity at presentation); tracking the longer-term implications for recovered COVID-19 patients; mental health indicators (including population surveys, calls to helplines, service utilization, rates of suicides and attempts); surveillance on the impact of non-pharmaceutical interventions (including mobility data, excess drug and alcohol usage, as well as domestic abuse incidents and hotline utilization); and economic factors (including unemployment and furlough rates; household spending on healthcare).</li>
    <li><strong>Model and estimate long-term implications.</strong> This process requires monitoring leading indicators of future health burdens (such as unemployment, and the utilization of services that support people with chronic or long-term problems), as well as modelling the future implications of current service disruption (for example, oncology surveillance).</li>
    <li><strong>Act on the result of detailed reporting.</strong> Clarity about where regional pressure points of non-COVID-19 morbidity and mortality are occurring, as well as having an understanding of the reported cause of death. In addition, specific attention should be placed on vulnerable populations, such as those with chronic health conditions, the elderly, individuals experiencing homelessness, people who are unemployed, women, or other underserved populations.</li>
</ul>
<h2>Consideration No. 2 Accelerate, de-risk, and prioritize the return to the next normal</h2>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="mck-c-inline-module-container SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__bgimg-wrapper__Qj4Dt mck-o-sm-left-span SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper__Dpjw2 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper--istablet__IQ6ii mck-u-screen-only mck-c-module-wrapper" data-layer-region="sidebar"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__epoAm  mck-o-md-center"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons-wrapper__9gB_c"><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons___eQy6"><div data-component="mdc-c-dropdown-menu" class="mdc-c-drop-down"><button data-component="mdc-c-button" aria-label="" type="button" id="floating-ui-5" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--ghost mdc-c-button--size-medium mdc-c-drop-down__rootmenu___yJzvz_990311c" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="menu"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--default___f-hQM_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-share2-icon"></span><span>Share</span></button><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="white" data-module-category="" class=""></div></div><button data-component="mdc-c-button" aria-label="Expandable Sidebar" type="button" id="button_id" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--ghost mdc-c-button--size-medium SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__toggle-btn__EL8iE" aria-expanded="false" data-layer-event-prefix="UI Item" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-category="sidebar" data-layer-subcategory="open" data-layer-text="open sidebar"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--radial___y3csX_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-xxl___cL3ZT_990311c mck-plus-no-circle-icon"></span></button></div></div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Cancer care may be delayed</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>Cancer is responsible for more than one-quarter of deaths recorded in Europe each year.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fb283e67-5948-42fa-95e9-dd95d0f11e11"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fb283e67-5948-42fa-95e9-dd95d0f11e11" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Still 1 in 4 deaths caused by cancer in the EU, Eurostat, February 3, 2016, ec.europa.eu.</span></span></span></a></span> Oncology services across Europe have seen significant delays and cancellations as health systems attempted to free up capacity for COVID-19.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7c41851c-ffa6-4c26-a5d9-70d809ecb74e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7c41851c-ffa6-4c26-a5d9-70d809ecb74e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Saini KS et al., Effect of the COVID-19 pandemic on cancer treatment and research, <em>Lancet</em>, April 24, 2020, thelancet.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Given the time-sensitive nature of cancer care, these delays could impede peoples recovery.</p>
<p>Systems should consider acting now to understand the size of the impact of COVID-19 on cancer patients within their systems, and develop robust plans to restart care at scale, catch up, and mitigate unnecessary deaths.</p>
<h3>Consideration 1</h3>
<p>Active monitoring of rates of cancer diagnostics and treatment can help. Increases in average wait times should ideally be avoided, and countries may want to continue to monitor average wait times to receive care. It may also be necessary to monitor potential consequences of delayed diagnosis and treatment. Such factors may include patients stage of cancer at diagnosis and potential impact on survival rates.</p>
<h3>Consideration 2</h3>
<p>Resuming cancer services to normal levels may be an urgent need. Where they do not already exist, European healthcare systems could consider establishing dedicated cancer care facilities. This may be achieved by working as part of a network to consolidate cancer care at one site. For example, much of the cancer care across London is now being coordinated and delivered by a specialist cancer hub at The Royal Marsden NHS Foundation Trust.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f2b03111-55ff-4673-ae3b-f7a84cdf09f9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f2b03111-55ff-4673-ae3b-f7a84cdf09f9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The Royal Marsden, Cancer Hub to deliver treatment during coronavirus pandemic, NHS Foundation Trust, April 3, 2020, royalmarsden.nhs.uk.</span></span></span></a></span> This organization is similar to local consolidation of care happening in networks centered around the Instituto Nazionale dei Tumori di Milano in Italy, and the Netherlands Cancer Institute.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="263d98d5-04a2-44dd-8be5-6eec69f7b303"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="263d98d5-04a2-44dd-8be5-6eec69f7b303" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">van de Haar J et al., Caring for patients with cancer in the COVID-19 era, <em>Nature Medicine</em>, 2020, Volume 26, pp. 66571, nature.com.</span></span></span></a></span> As systems rebuild their capacity, some have turned to prioritizing patients based on clinical need and potential impact of treatment.</p>
<h3>Consideration 3</h3>
<p>A continued examination of diagnosed cancer rates in each country may be wise. In the Netherlands, there was a 40 percent decrease in cancer diagnoses in the first week of April, dropping from 3,500 to 1,983 cases. This decrease in new patients was across the cancer spectrum, and correlates to up to a 60 percent decrease in oncological surgery in academic hospitals.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="811fafe0-8199-4bea-8132-31b0801b42a0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="811fafe0-8199-4bea-8132-31b0801b42a0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey analysis based on available data and expert interviews w/e April 16, 2020, NOS, Gupta, Parliamentary documents, BVO NL, NHG, Zorgdomein, EenVandaag.</span></span></span></a></span> The decreases likely reflect deferred healthcare interactions that would lead to a cancer diagnosis and surgery. Investing now to increase capacity in cancer facilities could help address the potential fallout from this lack of care. This increased capacity includes both screening and early diagnosis programs as well as treatment capacity.</p>
<h3>Consideration 4</h3>
<p>Oncology patients may have a fear of infection that could be addressed. The fear of COVID-19 is likely driving a significant reduction in people seeking medical attention for suspected cancer symptoms, as evidenced by a drop in the number of urgent referrals for cancer diagnosis. In Scotland, referrals have dropped by more than 70 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1f6ab53e-b887-4fc3-9b96-7e096ca3a54d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1f6ab53e-b887-4fc3-9b96-7e096ca3a54d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Philpotts E, GP urgent cancer referrals decline by more than 70% as 'fewer patients come forward' Pulse, April 24, 2020, pulsetoday.co.uk.</span></span></span></a></span> Discussing with patients the safety measures during primary care appointments and their ability to seek specialist referrals may help. Some systems may consider establishing COVID-19-free primary care facilities and implementing robust triage processes to direct patients to the right care for their needs. Measures may be needed to support public confidence in not getting infected while at a healthcare facility.</p>
<h3>Consideration 5</h3>
<p>The transformative solutions being adopted by health systems more broadly, such as digital care modalities and remote monitoring tools, may have applications to support cancer care. Delivering as much care as clinically safe and possible remotely will reduce the in-person traffic in healthcare facilities and make establishing COVID-19-free pathways and facilities easier. An opportunity may also exist to accelerate the adoption of hospital-at-home models, where infusion therapies are delivered at a patients home. This particular kind of delivery may support the self-isolation and shielding of cancer patients with a compromised immune system.</p>
<h3>Consideration 6</h3>
<p>Academic research in the United Kingdom has estimated that delays across the full spectrum of cancer care due to COVID-19 could lead to 18,000 additional deaths in the country. If the same impact is seen across Europe, an additional approximation of 140,000 deaths could otherwise have been avoided.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d4f6ad2d-56cb-427e-a0e9-31134d35befe"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d4f6ad2d-56cb-427e-a0e9-31134d35befe" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Assumes same scale of delayed care and scale of impact across Europe. Scales 18,000 excess deaths in the United Kingdom to Europe based on population size.</span></span></span></a></span> Establishing a robust cross-sector cancer plan to deal with this crisis and mitigate these excess deaths should be considered a priority.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The speed at which health systems bring back urgent and elective care beyond COVID-19 is critical. In most countries in Europe, system capacity during the COVID-19 crisis has exceeded demand with a large proportion of the healthcare workforce temporarily stood down.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8c2aacf1-f8a9-437c-a823-6d1a7c6f72a0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">28</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8c2aacf1-f8a9-437c-a823-6d1a7c6f72a0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For example, 40.9 percent of acute hospital beds in the National Health Service (NHS) in England were unoccupied as of April 13, 2020, compared with an average of around 10 percent prior to the COVID-19 pandemic. See West D, NHS hospitals have four times more empty beds than normal, <em>Health Service Journal</em>, April 13, 2020, hsj.co.uk.</span></span></span></a></span> This capacity should be rapidly redeployed. Delays in cancer treatment are likely impact outcomes,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="af6800bc-05a4-425e-9ac1-2dc5ee34b6b6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">29</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="af6800bc-05a4-425e-9ac1-2dc5ee34b6b6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Huang, J et al., Does delay in starting treatment affect the outcomes of radiotherapy: a systematic review, <em>Journal of Clinical Oncology</em>, 2003, Volume 21, Number 3, pp. 55563.</span></span></span></a></span> while postponing screening may result in cancers being detected at a later stage, which also affects prognosis.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8d62ceb2-e222-4b2d-85ab-5a8ff87d2114"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">30</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8d62ceb2-e222-4b2d-85ab-5a8ff87d2114" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McPhail S et al., Stage at diagnosis and early mortality from cancer in England, <em>British Journal of Cancer</em>, 2015, Volume 112, pp. S10815.</span></span></span></a></span> The first procedures and specialties to restart will need to be carefully prioritized, considering both the acuity of care needs, and the impact of delaying or not delivering care. Health systems are focused on ensuring their supply chains, managing their capacity, and supporting the resilience of their workforce, as discussed in McKinseys April 24, 2020 article, <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/from-wartime-to-peacetime-five-stages-for-healthcare-institutions-in-the-battle-against-covid-19"><em>From wartime to peacetime: Five stages for healthcare institutions in the battle against COVID-19</em></a>.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="436ae490-712d-4ca1-a246-b06446b273c5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">31</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="436ae490-712d-4ca1-a246-b06446b273c5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Singhal S, Reddy P, Dash P, and Weber K, <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/from-wartime-to-peacetime-five-stages-for-healthcare-institutions-in-the-battle-against-covid-19">From wartime to peacetime: Five stages for healthcare institutions in the battle against COVID-19</a>, April 24, 2020, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h2>Consideration No. 3 Invest in catching up</h2>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper--istablet__IQ6ii mck-u-screen-only mck-c-module-wrapper" data-layer-region="sidebar"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__epoAm  mck-o-md-center"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons-wrapper__9gB_c"><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons___eQy6"><div data-component="mdc-c-dropdown-menu" class="mdc-c-drop-down"><button data-component="mdc-c-button" aria-label="" type="button" id="floating-ui-7" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--ghost mdc-c-button--size-medium mdc-c-drop-down__rootmenu___yJzvz_990311c" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="menu"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--default___f-hQM_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-share2-icon"></span><span>Share</span></button><div
